summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from May 17, 2021, covering a wide range of national security, law enforcement, and political topics. It includes sections on the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, Capitol violence investigations, domestic terrorism, criminal investigations (including a mention of the Epstein case), and other Washington news. The document is a daily intelligence summary for FBI leadership.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in a Politico analysis discussing how numerous women played a key role in enabling his sex trafficking ring.

persons.name: Joel Greenberg
persons.context: Pleaded guilty to six charges including paying a minor for sex and agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in a case tied to Rep. Matt Gaetz.

persons.name: Matt Gaetz
persons.context: Florida politician under investigation; associate Joel Greenberg pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: Commented on the Colonial Pipeline attack, stating critical infrastructure is not adequately protected.

persons.name: Enrique Tarrio
persons.context: Announced creation of the 'Ministry of Self Defense' within the Proud Boys, mentioned in context of Capitol siege investigation.

persons.name: Ethan Nordean
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy in the Capitol siege, part of the Proud Boys' 'Ministry of Self Defense'.

persons.name: Joseph Biggs
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy in the Capitol siege, part of the Proud Boys' 'Ministry of Self Defense'.

persons.name: Zachary Rehl
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy in the Capitol siege; allegedly took a leading role in planning Proud Boys activities for January 6.

persons.name: Charles Donohoe
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy in the Capitol siege, part of the Proud Boys' 'Ministry of Self Defense'.

persons.name: Liz Cheney
persons.context: Removed from House GOP conference chair position; criticized for her stance against former President Trump's election claims.

persons.name: Elise Stefanik
persons.context: Elected to replace Liz Cheney as House Republican Conference Chair.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Frequently referenced in context of Capitol siege, election claims, and influence over the Republican Party.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned in various contexts including COVID-19 response, infrastructure, and reversing Trump-era executive orders.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Mentioned in context of reclassifying the 2017 baseball field shooting as domestic terrorism after Republican pressure.

persons.name: James O'Keefe
persons.context: Criticized The New York Times over a report about Project Veritas's activities.

connections.description: Greenberg is described as an associate of Gaetz and his plea agreement provides prosecutors a potential key witness against the congressman.
Both were leaders/members of the Proud Boys group charged with conspiracy related to the January 6 Capitol siege.
Both were leaders/members of the Proud Boys group charged with conspiracy related to the January 6 Capitol siege.
Both were leaders/members of the Proud Boys group charged with conspiracy related to the January 6 Capitol siege.
Both were leaders/members of the Proud Boys group charged with conspiracy related to the January 6 Capitol siege.
Cheney was removed from leadership for criticizing Trump's role in the January 6 attack and his election claims.
Stefanik was endorsed by Trump and parroted some of his false election claims during her campaign for conference chair.

events.title: Joel Greenberg Plea Agreement
events.description: Former Florida tax collector Joel Greenberg pleaded guilty to six federal charges, including paying a minor for sex, and agreed to cooperate fully with prosecutors, potentially implicating Rep. Matt Gaetz.

events.title: U.S. Capitol Siege
events.description: Ongoing criminal investigation into the January 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol; at least 411 suspects charged. Details emerge about Proud Boys planning through a 'Ministry of Self Defense'.

events.title: FBI Reclassifies 2017 Baseball Shooting
events.description: The FBI reclassified the 2017 shooting of Republican lawmakers at a baseball field in Alexandria, VA, from 'suicide by cop' to an act of domestic terrorism carried out by a 'domestic violent extremist'.

events.title: House GOP Leadership Change
events.description: House Republicans voted to replace Rep. Liz Cheney with Rep. Elise Stefanik as conference chair, a move driven by Cheney's criticism of former President Trump.

events.title: Colonial Pipeline Ransomware Attack
events.description: Cyberattack forced shutdown of Colonial Pipeline, causing gasoline shortages on East Coast. Hacking group DarkSide claimed responsibility; FBI confirmed involvement.

keyFacts: A Politico analysis highlighted that numerous women played a key role in enabling Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring.
Joel Greenberg, a former Florida tax official tied to the Gaetz probe, pleaded guilty to six charges including paying a minor for sex and agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors.
The FBI and DHS reported that deaths at the hands of racially motivated extremists are on the rise in the U.S., with 2019 being the most lethal year since 1995.
The FBI reclassified the 2017 shooting of Republican lawmakers at a baseball practice as domestic terrorism, reversing a prior 'suicide by cop' designation.
House Republicans replaced Liz Cheney with Elise Stefanik in leadership, solidifying the party's alignment with former President Donald Trump.
